comments.commentBody: The ability to "visit" off-the-tourist-track places via Google Maps is sometimes astonishing.  Google Earth's archive of older aerial imagery can be particularly revealing of beaches, such as Itacoatiara beach, Niterói, Brazil.  You can see some large wave events for this famous bodyboarding beach.

For the record, as one who used to wear Speedos when I swam lengths in my local pool, but no longer now I swim only in the sea, 'budgie smugglers' is Australian slang for the Speedos, not for the bloke wearing them.

For example, when Tony Abott made his maiden speech, he was not at the time wearing his famous budgie smugglers.

If a woman wants to cover herself at the beach... If a woman wants to walk topless on the beach.... Doesn't matter. This is her right in any western society. A burkini doesn't even cover the face. There is no security issue. We shouldn't be letting ourselves get to the point of forcing others to take off their clothes to live more peacefully. There's no sense in that. It's a swimsuit designed by an Australian, initially aimed at Muslim women (and others) living in the West to help them participate in popular Western cultural activities. The burkini is a sensible choice if you want to go swimming without revealing too much of your body, for whatever reason. To call it provocative is ridiculous. What of the freedom for which the French had a revolution?

Spouting racist undertones is a 'provocation' says every right minded person on the planet. People with an ounce of humanity have labelled Sarkozy a "provocation" that supports radical racism, as a heated debate rages on whether he is a supporter of FN. Forcing a woman to remove her clothes is a militant act, it's provocation that supports radical anti-Islamic sentiment. A lot of parents are putting their children in kids wetsuits rather than trunks / cossies these days. The sun is dangerous, nobody wants dirty old men eyeing up their kids, covering up is good and long may it continue.
IA
http://www.londonschoolofislamics.org.uk
I am a Muslim and he is a non-Muslim.

Everyone should have the right to be covered up at the beach.  The fear seems to be , if burkinies are permited, that will become the norm in the South of France.  As  history has shown us those  wearing the burkini are not usually the most tolerant of those not wearing it.  Those wearing the burkini will soon say," we are offended by people showing flesh on the beach'. They will then fight for their religious freedom saying it is part of their religion not to view immodestly "dressed" women on the beach. Have we not seen this before?

Why do they even bother to go to the beach, or the nature, if they are so afraid of exposing their precious pale-looking skin for beauty sake?

At least the muslims (and jews alike) have valid religious grounds for preserving modesty. These chinese in facekinis are all vanity, nothing more.

I've had to configure four AT&T gateways talking to six routers in the past six months, between water company pump sites and home network.  I can navigate their weird "IP pass-through" and  "cascaded router" interfaces in my sleep.  That's depressing.

Thanks, Martin. If memory serves me right - and I could be wrong - the 1959 White Sox won 31 games by one run (usually with a walk, a stolen base, a passed ball and a fly ball). That was about one third of their wins.

As for the game today, I would have preferred Heyward hit a three run homer but he blooped a single to score Rizzo (I think) from second.

Actually, it gives me hope that they are competitive with tams like the Dodgers and the Giants in low scoring games because the playoffs are mostly about pitching.

and Elke
John- welcome home. West is best.
Re your avatar- he got his start playing the guy who invented the phone. He had a long career- 58 years.

Martin,

I am feeling very frustrated tonight. The internet connection was lost when we returned from Maine.

BTW, the worst segments of the entire holiday were the cab rides to and back from the airport in Chicago. Otherwise the entire trip could not have been better.

So, after calling AT&T, which is a wonderful provider (I know because I spent hours on the phone today before they told me they couldn’t help me), we determined it was the 5 year old router and not the 14 year old modem. I bought a new router, which AT&T didn’t like and eventually sent me to the maker which told me how to connect in 10 minutes (after AT&T kept giving me bad advice for two hours).

I wish I could feel sorry for how the Cubs treated your Giants but I don’t.

The puzzle is Tracy-worth.

Prepared ribs and chicken for tomorrow’s Labor Day BBQ with the Chicago family.

Never looked at a puzzle the entire time I was gone.

Maine is not another state. It is another planet, like Avatar.
I hated writing "as per usual", though I knew it was the needed fill. Fingernails on chalkboard.

USC will be rated in the middle of the Pac 12, and it will be out of the top 25.  Alabama trounced a so-so team.  I wouldn't give them the championship yet.  Most notably, there are a couple of Big 10 powers that will likely give everyone else a run for the money.

Welcome back, amico. I feel the same way about the Pacific Northwest, Maine's mirror image.

One-run games shouldn't count.

I've had to configure four AT&T gateways talking to six routers in the past six months, between water company pump sites and home network.  I can navigate their weird "IP pass-through" and  "cascaded router" interfaces in my sleep.  That's depressing.
quite doable Sunday puzzle. got the rebus theme with elbows and B&O railroad. like A&R root beer and S&P five hundred. did know slush and You Lose!
I'm not entirely sure about that; Lophophora is the genus for the PEYOTE cactus, and there are various species. (Wiki lists about a half-dozen.) Perhaps safe(r) to say there is only ONE Mescaline?

Thanks, Martin. If memory serves me right - and I could be wrong - the 1959 White Sox won 31 games by one run (usually with a walk, a stolen base, a passed ball and a fly ball). That was about one third of their wins.

As for the game today, I would have preferred Heyward hit a three run homer but he blooped a single to score Rizzo (I think) from second.

Actually, it gives me hope that they are competitive with tams like the Dodgers and the Giants in low scoring games because the playoffs are mostly about pitching.

and Elke
John- welcome home. West is best.
Re your avatar- he got his start playing the guy who invented the phone. He had a long career- 58 years.

People say the reason to vote for clinton is her experience. Hence by definition she must have known how these conflicts of interest would look. Hence she set up a private server in order to hide that. She deleted records she had the experience to know enough to keep well she had her lawyers do her dirty work in order to maintain plausible deniability). she did exactly the same thing with mills and Huma. they did the dirty work (that's why they still are there) and she pleads I don't recall. When folks raised the issue of her server, another henchman for clinton said don;t mention it again. There is no direct evidence because the entire set up if she was caught was designed to make sure there was no direct evidence. I'm afraid if one examines the entire set of evidence there is no other conclusion. Having aides working for multiple organizations lets them sate they were working in a different role at the time. files were deleted after freedom of information requests. her prior justifications have been proven false for setting up the server. These are just too many improbable coincidences for it to be simple mistakes, or innocent. If you believe otherwise I have a bridge to sell you. I'm a life long dem. Other dems need a reality check. She makes Nixon look good, I watched the watergate hearings as a child
DCB, don't bogart that spliff, it is my last day of calm and I turn of channel 5 to avoid poopy snakes. I know it is hard to be objective...

It's worth noting that Russia has twice the uranium reserves as the US, and Russian ally Kazakhstan is the largest uranium producer in the world.
In short, it's not as if the Russian company is desperate for uranium. Its deal with the US producer was mainly just another commercial deal— not an ideological statement.
p.s.
Canada is the second largest producer of uranium, and another staunch US ally, Australia, is the third.
It's not as if the US will suddenly suffer a shortfall of suppliers.
The notion that the uranium deal was a threat to the US is nonsense.

"Meanwhile, we have the presumption that anything Hillary Clinton does must be corrupt, most spectacularly illustrated by the increasingly bizarre coverage of the Clinton Foundation."

Bizarre? I'll tell you what's bizarre... An election cycle in which everything but the issues of the day are debated. An election cycle in which the favorite to win hasn't given a press conference in nearly 280 days. An election cycle in which voters are disgusted by money in politics and the havoc it is wreaking and Paul Krugman wondering why there is criticism of the Clinton Foundation.

Well, for all the good it does - and hardly anyone denies it does do good - when you're Secretary of State or President of the United States, you're not supposed to be connected to an institution that accepts money from corporations and foreign entities, including Ukrainian nuclear power concerns at a time when nuclear power is on your list of to-do's at State. You're also not supposed to nominate donors to sensitive boards. But Clinton did nominate Rajiv Fernando. It looks bad, even when the intentions are the best.

Clinton, especially in view of the scrutiny she has always been under, should totally disconnect. If Bill is to have a job in her administration, then they should put the foundation in mothballs. That would be the right thing to do.

That's basis ethics 101, Professor Krugman.

---

www.rimaregas.com
Tony Abbott not 'Tony Abott'.

So true. And the MSM gleefully report that Mrs. Clinton's faulty memory are "proof" that she's up to something.
The NYTimes should now do a full report on the Clinton Foundation and compare it to other foundations, even such as are "Republican". That would be a very great service.
Also: how will the debate moderators: - Lester Holt, Anderson Cooper, Martha Raddatz and Chris Wallace - "moderate" the presidential debates? (If there even are some - one hears Trump looking for a way to go AWOL). Has Trump ever had to swear to testimony? If Trump were a witness anywhere in America, he'd have a string of perjury sentences (although after the first, he'd be in Leavenworth). How is it possible for Mrs. Clinton to even shake Trump's hand? I couldn't do it (there's not enough soap in America to clean one's hands after shaking Trump's).
Please, Mr. K., get the NYT to go after Trump's taxes and his scams. God help us if we have to live with such as Trump and his comic-book surrogates.

,

Exactly correct.  "I don't know" is exactly descriptive of Trump's core mentality...he does not know--about anything!  He is a "know-nothing" snake oil salesman...the only thing he does seem to know is how to steal money from others and lying with every word in the process.

It's not just the media who are using innuendo to cast shadows on Hillary Clinton. Donald Trump uses innuendo constantly.

"I don't know" is a familiar phrase he uses following an attack based on innuendo. "People are saying" and "I heard" are usually followed by other claims without substance. He's a master at the paranoid style and is rarely called out for it by the media that has a double standard for Sec'y Clinton.

I totally agree with this column. It would be terrible, and that's an understatement, if we had another Florida. I am tired of the way the press is covering this, Hillary=Bad, Trump=he may be better. I hope people see through this "coverage." If those who cover Hillary like this get their way, at the least, anotuher Florida. At most, good-bye to all that. And lastly, with the 2000 election, Hillary, and Bill won't be passive like Gore was, never speaking himself, sending Joe Liberman to do the work. And we'll see what Trump and the GOP do then in gthe face of constant assult by the Clintons and their allies.
He also lied and stated that less than 10% of Foundation funds go to programs.  The real number almost 90%.

I have noticed that after MSNBC recently shuffled up its programming to be more "news like" it has installed not only the news ticker tape on the bottom of the screen, but also invites in many very right leaning and not very bright commenters.  They still have Michael steele, but have managed to make the news with comments from a couple of trump surrogates who seem to be way out of their league.

Until yesterday, I had no idea who Alex Castellanos is.

I stumbled across Meet the Press, and he had me talking back to the TV before they'd even put his name on the screen. His assertions about the Clinton Foundation were absolutely over the line. In calling the foundation a 'slush fund' he implied that its filings and the Clinton's financial disclosures are fraudulent, and no one could be bothered to call him on that.

I don't understand how someone like that can be given a voice all, let alone invited into prominent venues to spread lies.

Full disclosure here. I have an extreme bias against Alex Castellanos. For that reason, I seldom watch CNN. To my dismay, he showed up yesterday on MSNBC. I have no idea if he has changed stables or if MSNBC, contrary to its political DNA, has hired on commentators from the deep right. Mr. Castellanos, in a roundtable discussion, said "the Clinton Foundation is nothing but a slush fund." And he topped it off, smirk and glee apparent, with "Trump is inching up in the polls."

It's quite understandable that networks have their biases and their political programming has become boringly predictable (Walter Cronkite, Eric Sevareid, Roger Mudd, where have you gone?)

If one can understand what's being said through the annoying cross-talk, one finds that almost all network political discussion is unfavorably geared towards Mrs. Clinton. And, yes, Dr. Krugman, 2016 feels a lot like 2000. It seems as though one is sitting in a darkened movie house watching a horror film that one has seen before but cannot turn away from the inevitable horrific denouement.

When W. said, in effect, "hey, have a beer with me," the railroad bells and horns and semaphores all went off. The presidency is a serious job, not Animal House. W., unsuited for the office, was used by Dick Cheney, naive fool that he was. And Donald Trump is different...how?

The Clinton Foundation is not on the ballot on November 8 but the future of our country is. Hillary Clinton is not the problem, people. Donald Trump is.

The problem is that there is some there there, but it is neither as damning nor as ubiquitous as the news media and Trump would have you believe. In the context of politics, it's pretty minor league, but you'd never know that from the way it's reported. People "know" that Clinton is untrustworthy and the narrative continues to be built on a very shaky foundation. I fear that the media isn't capable of fulfilling their responsibility as the Fourth Estate.

Agree completely. When it comes to Clinton scandals "there is no there there." never has been, never will be. Meanwhile, Trump's mendacity knows no bounds. There is no comparison. Shame on the media for pretending otherwise.

Jesus not so upset about money lending as he was about usury-inordinately high interest rates much like credit card companies(big banks),student loans ,etc. Why the Catholic Church only let the Jews do it and it was  a terrible sin for Christians to be money lenders or bankers.

to rosedhu2:
Sorry. The Gospels in all versions of Jesus and the money changers make reference only to merchants and money changers. The Gospels do not, under any circumstances make reference to usury by anyone in these exchanges. There is no money lending here in these traditions, Rather there is currency exchange due to pilgrims coming with different types of currencies and market activity, the episodes apparently took place near markets, remains of some have been found in excavations in Jerusalem.
Christian policy in the Middle Ages re lending money and/or usury has absolutely nothing to do with those Jesus episodes.

My friend, Mr. Schwatz, Charles' reading is contemporary, not portraying history, but focused on contemporary accuracy: Donald Trump as the money changer (secular!) has entered the temple (a common African-American reference used for independent, non-denominational places of worship). Africans sold slaves, it is not anti-black to point this out, although it can be in specific contents, depending on intent. So with the faults and foibles of others; all whites, even his supporters can't be judged by Donald Trump's reckless, immoral inner void; nor can an incident in this content even inadvertently suggest bias. We cannot fault or fear our truth. And I agree the sins of humanity should be not an invitation to blame and condemnation, but an earnest sharing that furthers and invites redemption and forgiveness of and for all who awake and take refuge in the source of our help.

"....that a black pastor had invited this money changer into the temple to defile it."

I shall ignore the fact that that there no money changers in the temple (Greek: naos), but rather Jesus was upset by monetary activity taking place somewhere in the temple mount complex (Greek: hieron) (and the purported location is still a matter of scholarly dispute). By using this image, Mr. Blow manages to add an acerbic, ironic edge to the Jewish prayer shawl given to Mr. Trump, and, unfortunately, the image also adds a tinge of underlying anti-Semitism. While I am certain beyond a doubt that Mr. Blow had no intention of this, it goes to show the power of words and images which take on a life of their own. Meaning is not always what the author of the words intends them to mean.

"Everything about Trump reads to me as false". Agreed. Unfortunately I am not convinced by Mrs. Clinton and much about her reads to me as false (and let it be clear, I support neither; I am not writing out of support for one candidate or another).

"...and I hope that on Election Day, America exercises the gift of discernment". Alas, I fear that Mr. Blow is too optimistic. Polls indicate that Mr. Trump is closing the gap.

This was just another vaudeville presentation, a close encounter of the Trump kind. It's alarming that so few in the media and nobody in government will hold his feet to the fire. His history of prior bad acts, his pride in success through subterfuge, his cowardly association with seditious travelers, the murky history of his current wife's immigration, his embrace and encouragement of foreign antagonists and his pathetic need for adulation and attention have all been documented, but not so much memorialized. Even taken separately, someone with less of a parade balloon persona would have faced serious consequences and dire legal troubles for any of those transgressions, yet DJT gets a walk. Neither running for office nor running your mouth imparts any immunity. He clearly thinks he's too big to jail ("I could shoot someone..."). He likewise thinks most of us are dumb, toothless goobers.
As a showman he has no problem staging a foray into hostile territory, and staged it was. Not just scripted to a tee, but I have to wonder if those few that did attend might have gotten inducements, if not actor's scale. I guess he felt it wasn't worth paying all the extras needed to fill all those empty seats.
I'm guessing he won't attend the debates on some pretext (little league is holding tryouts that night and they wrote him a letter?) Or maybe he has a prior commitment to walk on water somewhere else?
HeyNorris has nailed it. So should the NYT, the DOJ, DHS and such. Pravda not so much.
That Huffington Post disclaimer ought to be prologue, not postscript, to ANY coverage of the demagogue in ANY source.  It is not an afterthought; it precedes anything coming from Trump.  Period.

For clarification... I support Sec. Clinton for president.
The 'crooked president Hillary campaign' are trumps words NOT MINE.

One of the many things I admire in Charles Blow is that, unlike the media in general and many of his OpEd cohorts, he doesn't try to have it both ways. We always know exactly where he stands, and his passion is usually backed up by facts.

Which is what we have here, in his analysis of Trump's pathetic and shameful "outreach" trip to Detroit. The evidence that Trump is a bigot (or is at least portraying himself as a bigot for perverse reasons too twisted to understand), is overwhelming and indisputable.

Bless you, Mr. Blow, for spelling it out. What I'd like to know, though, is why your employer doesn't do the same in its Trump coverage.

The following disclaimer appears at the end of every article about Trump in the Huffington Post: "Editor’s note: Donald Trump regularly incites political violence and is a serial liar, rampant xenophobe, racist, misogynist and birther who has repeatedly pledged to ban all Muslims... from entering the U.S.", with links to proof points of each assertion.

I'm no great fan of HuffPo, but at least they understand the stakes and are willing to spell out the danger Trump poses. I imagine that kind of bluntness must feel distasteful to the Gray Lady's editors, but Trump is a distasteful, repugnant candidate that won the Republican nomination with plenty of help from the media.

It's now time for the media to take off the white gloves and beat back the monster they helped create.
The Bible passage Trump read was Kellyanne Conway's choice, as were the rest of the words Trump said. Steve Bannon's Trump, who we saw in Phoenix on Wednesday, will show up very soon.

Yes Bob West, the evangelicals are so crazed by religious doctrine and intolerance that Trump actually makes sense to them. Me, I live in the fact based universe.

I'm with HRC.

This is an anecdotal comment but I think it shows something of the way some GOP voters feel about Trump. I live in a fairly wealthy northern suburb of Atlanta. During the last presidential elections dating back to 2000 when I moved to this area there were yard signs in basically every yard for the GOP ticket. This election I have seen exactly 2 Trump yard signs. My neighbors have not changed parties to my knowledge, but they are showing a large tendency to not back Trump in the way they so enthusiastically backed Bush/McCain/Romney.

His reciting a passage from the bible, no matter what chapter, was enough to make one gag! Has he no shame! Have the evangelicals no shame, backing this phony bag of wind? Are they so blind by their intolerance of other religions, that they can't see through his thin skin and lies?
Sorry.  It is Mr. Blow and I realized that just now.  I'd edit if I could.

Perhaps the best assessment of Trump that I have read. There wasn't one word which needed to be changed.

Mr. Douthat speaks from the anger of one who sees his life's work and beliefs being torn into shreds. Trump and his supporters are the agent. But too many within the GOP during the reign of the conservatives spent too long courting the very elements of their own destruction - racists, government haters, and single issue voters of varied stripes.

This thorough renunciation may be too little/too late for the GOP. May it not be too late for our nation.
Where is it documented?
Really?  I did some research about "the full access to material he needs..."  It not only isn't well documented, there's no proof I can find anywhere.  Source, please.

Well, since the election is already decided (4 to 1) two months out....we can all just relax now, and stop angsting. Right? Why is everyone so "worried" if Trump is guaranteed to lose?

Crook, liar, fraud -- Hillary is your Anointed One, the new Empress over us all.

All hail The Anointed One!

The odds are still 4:1 against Trump getting elected.

1. I read a column by Ms Dowd, who said that Trump was so bad, everyone must vote for Secretary Clinton in spite of her flaws. The top rated comments were all 'Fire Ms Dowd for lying. Secretary Clinton has no flaws at all.' Certainly, Prof Krugman agrees with those comments.

2. On 29 August, Snopes noted that the Clinton Foundation had received the highest rating by CharityWatch. They noted that CharityWatch is not the best of the charity-rating agencies, and CharityNavigator refused to rate the Clinton Foundation because of irregularities. On 1 Sept, CharityNavigator due to "unprecedented demand" not only reinstated the Clinton Foundation's, but gave it their top rating. So, when the Clintons heard about the Snopes article, Bill got on top of things.

3. As Prof Krugman says, one must go by actions, not words. Trump vehemently denies climate change, and has fought against renewable energy. He would be an unmitigated disaster as president.

Someone pointed out that charges that Senator Clinton voted for war, and Secretary Clinton strongly supported war are false to any native English speaker: in plain English, it's only a war if a majority of both houses of Congress vote to call it a war. Military actions to force regime change are NOT wars without that vote, they're just peace-keeping missions.

And Secretary Clinton has promised peacekeeping missions to liberate Syria and Russia as soon as she takes office.

More Green eggs and Hillary

I will not vote for you "Hillary I am"!
I'd rather eat green eggs and ham.
I will not vote for you in a pinch.
Though beating Trump is such a cinch.

I do not trust you "Hillary I am"!
You do not have an honest face.
I do not want you in our house
pull your lever and I'm a louse.

I will not vote for you "Hillary I am".
I'd rather eat green eggs and ham.
Bernie Sanders had a plan.
You are running and loosing the race.

I wish Hillary showed more fire,
More left leaning words that inspire,
Daily her lead's slipping
Is momentum tipping?
Presaging an ending that's dire?

A Trumpian POTUS is scary
A bully that is feral hairy,
In coming debate
Hill'ry must deflate
This menace and make voters wary.

There is a glaring distinction between an on the books donation to a foundation from a Ukrainian nuclear (that would be "nu-kyu-ler" to W) power lobby, and an off the books cash payment to one's erstwhile campaign chairman from a Ukrainian tyrant and thief.  As usual, the mendacities of Orange Julius Caesar are like a swirling flock of starlings, so numerous and shifting as to defy concentration on any single one. One surrogate after another proves to be either risibly ignorant of current events, a liar, or both.
